Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Global assessment of the causes and consequences of commonness and rarity in freshwaters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human activity has caused a decline in global biodiversity through resource overexploitation, habitat modification, and introduction of non-native species. When rare species are lost, communities exhibit decreased functionality and provide devalued services to humans, which is an environmental and a socioeconomic problem. Although biodiversity loss is global and affects all ecosystems, biodiversity in freshwaters is threatened by much higher extinction rates compared to terrestrial habitats. Therefore, a better understanding of the causes and extent of rarity in freshwaters is urgently needed. Species rarity can be assessed using the species abundance distribution (SAD), which is a measure of the relative abundances of common and rare species. Although the SAD has been investigated for more than 70 years, little is known about the underlying mechanisms that determine the patterns of abundance inequality. The study will address this knowledge gap by developing a novel framework which predicts the response of the SAD in freshwater habitats along environmental and spatial gradients. The study will also investigate how the SAD affects regional biodiversity. Finally, the study will inform decisions for watershed management and biodiversity preservation by elucidating the causes of rarity in species targeted for conservation. This project will also provide research training for one postdoctoral associated, one graduate student and several undergraduate students.

This project formulates specific hypotheses, predicting the SAD variability in response to niche and dispersal-related mechanisms as a function of scale, body size, and connectivity. These hypotheses will be tested with global data on freshwater algae, invertebrates, and fish, collected from running and standing waters by US and foreign agencies. Then, it will be determined how, in turn, the SAD constrains the patterns of beta diversity, a key component of regional biodiversity, by employing null model approaches. The SAD of communities and species groups of conservational or environmental importance will be fit with appropriate models. The variability of the parameters of these models will be analyzed statistically along gradients of water chemistry, climate, land use, latitude, longitude, and altitude, and across scales, habitats, and organismal groups. Implementation of the proposed framework would lead to better integration of metacommunity ecology and conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. Biological communities worldwide, but especially in freshwaters, are threatened by human-caused habitat loss and degradation due to land use, eutrophication (increased nutrient inputs), acidification, and climate change. Using experimental data on biofilm algae and global observational data on stream diatoms, insects, and fish, Dr. Sophia Passy and her international team of PhD students and scientists from the US, France, Finland, and Canada, demonstrated how species and communities respond to changes in their environment. Existing theories explaining local and biogeographical patterns of biodiversity and species composition were tested and new models were proposed when established theories were inconsistent with observations.

In the first intercontinental comparative study of species richness, commonness, and rarity in freshwaters, the team showed that contrary to many theories predicting an overarching effect of climate, biodiversity in stream diatoms and their abundance distributions were co-controlled by both nutrients and climate. New, nutrient-climate models were developed to describe the biogeographical patterns of these community properties, which would be particularly useful, given the ongoing eutrophication of freshwaters. Another study, using lab microcosms and in situ stream manipulations, experimentally demonstrated for the first time that not only nutrient amounts but also the number of added nutrients had a profound impact on algal community structure and function. The discovery that biodiversity increased with the number of added nutrients challenged the predictions of one of the most influential theories in ecology, resource competition theory. This research confirmed that an alternative theory, the benthic model, adequately explained the observed biodiversity patterns and, therefore, must be adopted in stream research.

In a series of studies, the team explored the patterns and drivers of regional biodiversity, measured as beta diversity or spatial turnover. Thus, a comparative study of beta diversity between natural (forest) and human-dominated land cover (agriculture) in the US, Canada, and France revealed that agriculture led to biotic homogenization of diatom, insect, and fish communities, whereby streams became more similar in terms of species composition. The observed homogenization was attributed to an excess of common species and stronger dominance in agriculture. A second investigation on diatom beta diversity in US and French streams also detected homogenization and ascribed it to eutrophication causing elimination of specialist species. Biotic homogenization is of environmental concern because it may impede ecosystem resilience following disturbance. However, biotic heterogenization, i.e. increased beta diversity, can also be a cause of concern, as suggested by a third investigation by the team, performed in the Adirondacks—one of the most acid-impacted regions in the US. This collaborative study between the PI's lab and the US Geological Survey showed that diatom beta diversity decreased with severity but increased with heterogeneity of acid stress. It cautioned that a higher beta diversity in a stressed system may not be a sign of ecological integrity, as in non-impacted habitats, but of impending environmental degradation and future loss of sensitive species should the stress continue to spread. In a fourth investigation, the largest in the US to date, the PI's team explored the current distributions of diatom, insect, and fish species in streams and their future range shifts under climate change. They projected a widespread increase of warm-water species, outpacing the decline of cold-water species and thus giving rise to biotic homogenization. This series of investigations improved our understanding of the current and future factors leading to biotic homogenization and heterogenization in stream communities, necessary for designing appropriate conservation and biomonitoring programs.            

Broader impacts. Texas Stream Team is a 28-year-old statewide organization involving citizen scientists in monitoring the 191,000 miles of waterways in Texas. In 2018, the PI's lab founded the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) Stream Team, whose mission is to educate the public about water quality issues, engage it in citizen science, and contribute to the monitoring efforts of the City of Arlington. All members of the PI's lab became certified Texas Stream Team trainers and taught undergraduate students from a variety of science and engineering departments at the UTA how to collect water samples, measure physico-chemistry, and assess water quality. Graduate and undergraduate student members of the UTA Stream Team monitored small wadable streams and the obtained data complemented the data collection by the City of Arlington, whose monitoring program focuses primarily on larger water bodies.

Summary. This research resulted in seven published articles in leading ecology and microbiology journals, one submitted manuscript, eight presentations at regional, national, and international conferences, mentoring of one postdoctoral researcher, three PhD students, and sixteen undergraduate students, many from underrepresented groups (i.e., nine women, five Hispanic, and one African American), and the establishment of the UTA Stream Team.
